title: Identify slow test
description:
Run tests with timing output to identify which test(s) are taking a long time.

Approach:
1. Run tests serially (not in parallel) using 'bun test --rerun-each 1' or similar to isolate timing
2. Set a 2-minute (120 second) timeout - any test still running after 2 minutes is considered slow
3. Use '--timeout 120000' flag if available, or manually track time
4. Run each test file individually if needed to isolate the slow one(s)
5. Report which specific test file and test case is slow

The goal is to identify the slow test quickly, not to wait for it to complete.

title: Evaluate and fix slow test
description: Once the slow test is identified, understand what it does and why it exists. If the test is not necessary (e.g., testing the old slow backtracking generator that we've replaced with the Python Latin cube construction), delete it. If it is necessary, optimize it or mark it as a known slow test.

title: Port Python Latin cube generator to TypeScript
description:
Port the mathematical Latin cube construction from generate_cube.py to src/services/generator.ts.

The Python implementation uses:
- cell_value(r, c, z) function that computes values using base-4 digit decomposition and XOR (GF(4) arithmetic)
- Instant O(1) per-cell computation instead of backtracking
- check_all() validation for all constraints

Steps:
1. Read generate_cube.py to understand the cell_value() formula
2. Implement the same logic in TypeScript in generator.ts
3. Replace generateSolvedCube() to use the mathematical construction
4. Keep generatePuzzle() which removes cells for difficulty (this part is fast)
5. Add validation to ensure the generated cube satisfies all constraints
6. Run bun test to verify nothing breaks
7. Run bun run build to ensure compilation succeeds

The result should be instant puzzle generation in the browser without needing pre-cached puzzles.

title: Create centralized rendering config
description:
Multiple renderers (SceneManager, CubeRenderer, MinimapRenderer, ValueSpriteRenderer) define their own config interfaces with duplicated default values. Some duplication is problematic, but some is intentional:

PROBLEMATIC DUPLICATION (should centralize):
- backgroundColor: 0x1a1a1a (same in SceneManager and MinimapRenderer)
- Lighting config: ambient 0.6, directional 0.8 (identical in SceneManager and MinimapRenderer)
- filledOpacity: 0.6 (same in CubeRenderer and MinimapRenderer)
- Main scene cameraDistance defined in BOTH SceneManager default AND main.ts

INTENTIONAL DIFFERENCES (keep separate):
- Minimap has smaller cellSize (0.8 vs 1.0) - it's a miniature view
- Minimap has smaller cellGap (0.05 vs 0.1)
- Minimap has different cameraDistance (30 vs 37.5) - closer for small viewport
- Minimap emptyOpacity (0.1) differs from CubeRenderer (0.05) - may be intentional for visibility

Solution:
1. Create src/config/RenderConfig.ts with SHARED constants only
2. Export COLORS, LIGHTING, and shared opacity values
3. Keep renderer-specific configs (cellSize, cameraDistance) in their respective files
4. Document which values are shared vs intentionally different
5. main.ts should not duplicate values that match defaults
close_reason: Closed

title: Default to outermost layer when entering face-on view
description:
When switching to face-on view, always default to the outermost layer visible from the camera's perspective.

Current behavior: May default to layer 7 or preserve previous layer
Required behavior: Always start at the 'front' of the cube for that face

Determining outermost layer:
- For i-face (looking down X): outermost depends on camera X position (layer 0 or 15)
- For j-face (looking down Y): outermost depends on camera Y position (layer 0 or 15)
- For k-face (looking down Z): outermost depends on camera Z position (layer 0 or 15)

Generally, if camera is on the positive side of the axis, outermost is layer 15. If negative, layer 0.

Key change: In ViewStateManager.enterFaceOnView(), determine the outermost layer based on current camera position before setting face-on view.
close_reason: Completed in commit 5158b43. ViewStateManager.enterFaceOnView() now accepts optional layer parameter and defaults to outermost layer based on camera position. GameUI face buttons use automatic outermost layer selection. All quality gates pass (type-check, lint, build, tests).
